subject: Back In The USA
event:
So we're back home in Santa Fe, after ten days on the road in Germany, Sweden, and Finland.

A wonderful trip, all in all.  Yes, much of it was work... I did numerous interviews in Hamburg, more in Stockholm, still more on the Alands, yadda yadda yadda... but in between we had some fine old times.  

Some highlights:
     -- touring MiniatureLand in Hamburg.  Wow.  Biggest toy train set in the world, but the landscapes and miniatures dwarf the trains.  Very glad my hosts took me to see this.
     -- the big public event in Hamburg, 3000 fans, sold out months ago.
     -- hanging with Sibel Kekilli and her boyfriend, and my German publicist, Sebastian.  Sibel fed me Turkish food and showed me some of Hamburg's nightlife, to reciprocate for the tour of Santa Fe I gave her on INTO THE NIGHT.  Hamburg stays up later than Santa Fe, you will be surprised to learn, but chile con queso is nowhere to be found.  We drank White Russians while huddled under blankets in an outdoor cafe.  Took a canal boat tour as well.    
      -- Stockholm.  What a gorgeous city.  Comes of not having a major war since Napoleon.  That way your gorgeous old buildings don't get bombed into rubble.  
      -- the Vasa Museum.  Okay, the ship never made it our of the harbor, but it makes a great centerpiece for a museum,
      -- the Royal Armory, where you can actually see the bloodstained clothing that Gustavus Adolphus and Charles XII were wearing when they died,
      -- Marieham, on the Aland islands.  Just a lovely place.
      -- the Aland Vikings, who fed us pancakes and mead and hammered at each other with axe and sword and spear for our amusement.  They are building a very cool Viking village, definitely worth a visit if you visit the islands.  

And of course Archipelacon was great fun as well.  The Finnish fans are second to none, and we had plenty of Swedes on hand as well, and a strong BWB contigent who taught them all how to party.  It is events like this that remind me what fandom is all about -- a celebration of science fiction and fantasy, of friendship and family.

comments.article:
Come here big guy, group hug.

On a side note, you have a big Iranian fan base George! Alas, dressing up like Daenerys for cosplay would result in... unpleasant consequences.
comments.subject: Friendship and family

comments.article: Will you be posting any of the interviews on here George?
Sounds marvelous.
comments.subject: Welcome home

comments.upictitle: the shining bacon of democracy: peacock snake eyes
comments.article: I very much enjoyed your talk and the reading in Hamburg. Sorry some of the guy's questions were a bit odd! :-)

I had exactly the same feeling.
And so few of them were actually related to a song of ice and fire.
I also hoped maybe the fans will get to ask some questions too.. I was overall a bit disappointed.
Can I only ask about your books etc or also about you in here?
comments.subject: Question

comments.article: Ask what you like.  I may... or may not... answer.
comments.subject: Re: Question

comments.article:
How glad am I that you have had a great time, even though it was work / business. Also glad that you got home OK (you spoke not of delays).

Enjoy the rest of your week, and weekend, and here's hoping it's 'back to it' on Monday, rather than sooner.

Glad you enjoyed Hamburg! The miniature land truly is a sight to behold, makes me so happy you liked it!
Truly a wonderful city, even more so than Berlin or other "famous" german cities in my opinion, but I may be biased since I really like the north of germany. ;)

Hey George, I listened to your Stockholm Q & A where you talked about having to come up with things to put on the ASOIAF map East of Qarth. It brought up a question I've wanted to ask you for a while..

When you write stories (I guess specifically complex epics like ASOIAF) do you almost always develop the locals & their customs / culture to support the plot of the story or do you develop some of the locals based solelyon what you think would be cool or interesting without direct regard to the story? I was thinking that doing the latter might end up helping you to come up with more interesting ways to get from point A to point B in the story than you originally intended. Am I right?

ALSO, I know you're sorely needed in LA where all the cinematic magic happens, but you've got tons of fans here in the North East who'd love to meet you in person! To entice you, we've got cheese steaks, soft pretzels and pizza that you just can't get anywhere else in the world!

Glad to hear you're back home again! It was a blast having you over and to co-chair a con with you as one of the GoHs. Next time in Helsinki!

-Johan
comments.subject: Good to hear you're back again

comments.article: Welcome home George    Hope you are able to make it to Chicago to share in the good times!!!
comments.subject: Fare Thee Well

comments.article:
Hi George, I heard you gave some praise to "The Meereenese Blot" during a Q&A on that trip, which is really cool to hear because those are some great essays!

Do you know of other examples of essays/blogs that impressed you? Or some that otherwise really interested you?

Asking for some friends who run blogs/podcasts :)

I live in Denmark but didn't have the time nor the money to visit any of my neighbouring countries while you were there. But I am glad to hear you had such a great time here in Northern Europe. Hope you will swing by Denmark next time!
comments.subject: So sorry I missed you.

comments.article: Hi george were you ever in dublin ireland for a sighing ??

So I walked past a bookstore at the mall today and saw right up front that they were selling copies of A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms in Spanish (I live in Peru).

I thought the book was coming out in October?
comments.subject: Question

comments.article: GRRM obviously has the final say here, but I think that the foreign language editions of A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms were published before the English edition, because some of the stories haven't been previously translated.  They were selling the Swedish edition at Archipelicon, and that's what another fan told me.
comments.subject: Reply from a fan

comments.article: You mentioned white russians, and it got me curious, do you have any preference in what you drink?  I'm guessing you had the chance to drink plenty of beer over in Germany!  I'm glad you had a great trip!!!
comments.subject: Beers/Spirits/Wine

comments.article:
I have got used to your livejournal Mr. Martin! It was a pleasure reading a new post after a while. I'm glad you enjoyed your voyage.

By the way, you've got many readers in Iran although you don't have an official publisher here. Just saying :) Hope you always be happy.
comments.subject: Northen Europe

comments.article: I have a question about the genesis of Tyrion; was he conceived as an amalgam of the dwarf ambassador and Lord Gro from the Worm Ouroboros?
comments.subject: Tyrion

comments.article:
Hi! I'm the gal who spoke about the adaptation of your novels into television at Archipelacon. May I just say thanks to you that you came and listened to my talk! Hopefully I didn't make a very bad impression. :)

I very much enjoyed the panels and such you did at the con. Especially the Q&A session after "The Lion and the Rose" was very intriguing. I'm currently doing my PhD about the adaptation of ASOIAF into GoT, and it was both professionally and fannishly speaking awesome to hear you talk about writing and adapting.

Best regards,
Anna-Leena Harinen
comments.subject: My humble thanks

comments.article: Head on over to Colorado!
comments.subject: Colorado

comments.article:
So exited to hear about your travels in the north! On your comments on the beauty of Stockholm I can't help but smile! The debate has been going on for 40 years now, why one of the least war-troubled cities in the world has less historical buildings than London! The story goes.. in the 1960's and 70'ies the ruling politicians of Stockholm torn down huge chuncks of the oldest part of town, and replaced it with contemporary buildings. This was hugley controversal at the time and could problaly not have been accomplished unless the building-wreckers waited until a hot summers weekend to start their demolishing. So, the real old Stockholm wasn't destroyed by wars, but due to ideological reasons that stated that "old buildiings are nothing but left-overs from a old (oppressive) regime not worth saving". The new Stockholm was built on the idea that everyone should be included, which of course is a noble idea, but shouldn't be the cause of destroying our history.

Anway! As a Swede I was happy to hear you visit my favourite museums in Stockholm! I always imagined you must have got some influence from our young boy king of the North, Carl XII, with his great military prowess and the rumors concerning he was untouchable in battle, and could only be killed with some means of magic. He was aswell killed in strange circumstances, some claim it was treachery.

Would have loved to come to your event at Sciencefiction bokhandeln but as a true northerner I hardly like our capital :)
comments.subject: Swedish history!
